>So said javainsel on 4/13/2003 --------------------
>1. We separate the te=
st cases in an own package. Is that best 
>practice?

There is debate on th=
is. I feel that it is best to test classes through a public interface. Othe=
rs believe that this leads to adding methods "only for testing". To me, tha=
t generally means that a design change is required. I use the restrictions =
it places on me to improve my design.

>2. When doing this, some methods wi=
th default (package) visiblilty 
>cannot be accessed. But when using the Re=
flection API, this methods 
>can be accessed. Is it okay to use the reflect=
ion? Or is it bad 
>style?

I consider it bad style to do so. I only test t=
hrough public interfaces. If I need to make an interface element "only for =
testing", then I look for the necessary design change.

>3. What about test=
ing private methods? It is normally not possible 
>if the test is in an own=
 class. But again I can use the reflection 
>to acess private methods. Shou=
ld I do that? Or should I only test 
>methods with public access?

If a pri=
vate method might break, then that method is doing some useful, complex wor=
k. If it is so useful and complex, then that work belongs on a different ob=
ject/class. In that case, the resulting change to the interface makes it pu=
blic.

I don't use package-level visibility, even though perhaps I could.

=
If you have many private methods in a class, then those private methods are=
 really a smaller class trying to get out of the larger class. This is my e=
xperience.

>Maybe this question has been asked. But I have problems 
>unde=
rstanding the nature of the search results in this forum.

It is healthy to=
 discuss them every so often.
